author: News
title: Barbara Corcoran: 1% Interest Rate Drop Will Send Housing Prices 'Through the Roof'
text: Barbara Corcoran, founder of The Corcoran Group and known for her role on "Shark Tank," said she would not be surprised if home prices increase by another 8% to 10%. (Shutterstock) Share | | Getting your Barbara Corcoran, founder of The Corcoran Group and known for her role on “Shark Tank,” recently discussed the potential shifts in the housing market during an interview on “ [Cavuto: Coast to Coast](https://www.foxbusiness.com/shows/cavuto-coast-to-coast).” Corcoran, a prominent figure in commerce, finance, and real estate, shared insights into how interest rates may impact housing prices and buyer behavior. “I can’t explain the rates going up or down – that’s not my bailiwick. But what I can explain is if rates go down, just another percentage point, that’s what I’m hoping for, prices are going to go through the roof,” Corcoran said in the interview. Related Story: [Coalition: CA Lawmakers Need to Roll Back Proposed ‘Utility Tax’](https://gvwire.com/2024/04/16/coalition-ca-lawmakers-need-to-roll-back-proposed-utility-tax/) Corcoran expressed optimism about the market if interest rates were to decrease, stating that even a one-percentage-point drop could significantly boost housing prices. “Everyone will come out and buy. There are probably 10 buyers on the sidelines waiting for interest rates to come down that are actually active in the market,” she continued. “So everybody’s going to charge the market.” Where Are Current Interest Rates? As of Wednesday, April 17, the interest rates for 30-year and 15-year fixed-rate mortgages were at 7.3% and 6.5%, respectively, [according to bankrate.com](https://www.bankrate.com/mortgages/15-year-mortgage-rates/). The Federal Reserve’s decision to maintain interest rates at a high level during its latest meeting was noted, which could keep mortgage rates and other borrowing costs elevated. “If you wait for interest rates to come down by another point, I don’t think you’ll gain. I think you’ll wind up paying more,” Corcoran cautioned. “Because I wouldn’t be surprised if real estate went up by another 8 or 10% if interest rates come down.” Related Story: [Wall Street’s Mixed Trading Day](https://gvwire.com/2024/04/16/wall-streets-mixed-trading-day/) Sellers Want the Most Money Corcoran also addressed predictions about house prices potentially decreasing due to sellers paying lower commissions. “A lot of people are predicting house prices will come down because the seller will pay less of a commission and take that difference and give it to the buyer,” she said. “Sellers aren’t made that way. When the seller lists a home, they want the most money they can get, so they’re going to take any savings and put it in their pocket.” Corcoran’s Market Outlook Regarding the overall market outlook, Corcoran highlighted the importance of addressing the housing supply shortage, which she views as a key factor that could propel the real estate market forward. “Whenever there’s uncertainty, people stall. And whenever people stall, it stalls the marketplace,” Corcoran noted. “But despite that, and overriding all of that, is a shortage of houses.” Corcoran’s analysis underscores the significant impact that interest rates and housing supply dynamics can have on real estate trends. For more information on this topic, visit [Fox Business](https://www.foxbusiness.com/real-estate/shark-tank-star-barbara-corcoran-reveals-housing-prices-through-roof).

author: Jacky
title: Founder of the American Family Association dies in Mississippi
text:
Donald Wildmon, founder of the American Family Association, a conservative Christian advocacy group, dies
TUPELO, miss. — Donald Wildmon, founder of the American Family Association, a conservative Christian advocacy group, has died, the organization announced Thursday.
The 85-year-old Mississippi native died Thursday of complications related to Lewy body dementia, according to an obituary published by WTVA-TV. Wildmon died in Tupelo, Mississippi, the city where the American Family Association is headquartered. The obituary referred to Wildmon as “one of the legendary leaders of American conservatism.”
“His impressive legacy of Christian ministry will endure for many years to come,” Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves, a Republican, said on X, formerly known as Twitter.
Wildmon founded the AFA, first known as the National Federation for Decency, in 1977 after working as a pastor of the United Methodist Church.
Since its inception, the conservative advocacy group has launched campaigns and boycotts to pressure corporations to avoid supporting causes the group opposes, such as anti-LGBT discrimination measures.
In 1991, Wildmon launched American Family Radio, which installed radio stations throughout the United States to spread the AFA message. Wildmon led the AFA for 33 years, the obituary said. He resigned in 2010 and his son, Tim Wildmon, now runs the organization.

author: Redacción AN / JOF
title: Reforma judicial de AMLO provocará tardanza en resolver problemas: Jueces del PJF | Aristegui Noticias
text: Reforma judicial de AMLO provocará tardanza en resolver problemas: Jueces del PJF La jueza Juana Fuentes Velázquez dijo que serán miles de personas afectadas por la separación de su cargo de todos los juzgadores que están en funciones a nivel federal y estatal, incluyendo a la población penitenciaria - Redacción AN / JOF La aprobación de una reforma judicial que contempla despedir a todos los jueces y magistrados del país, va a frenar el sistema de justicia en México, advirtió la directora de la Asociación Nacional de Magistrados de Circuito y Jueces de Distrito del Poder Judicial de la Federación (Jufed), Juana Fuentes Velázquez. En entrevista para Aristegui en Vivo, la jueza Fuentes Velázquez dijo que serán miles de personas afectadas por la separación de su cargo de todos los juzgadores que están en funciones a nivel federal y estatal, incluyendo a la población penitenciaria que se encuentra sujeta a la prisión preventiva, pero sin que se le haya dictado una sentencia. Te puede interesar > [ Gremio judicial perfila paro de labores contra la reforma de AMLO](https://aristeguinoticias.com/1308/mexico/gremio-judicial-perfila-paro-de-labores-contra-la-reforma-de-amlo/) En este marco, consideró lamentable que el presidente Andrés Manuel López Obrador se haya burlado de los trabajadores del Poder Judicial de la Federación al [ desestimar el paro de labores anunciado](https://aristeguinoticias.com/1408/mexico/lopez-obrador-desestima-aviso-de-huelga-del-poder-judicial-ante-reforma-judicial/) de manera conjunta por jueces, magistrados y trabajadores de juzgados y tribunales federales. Reconoció que siguen en pláticas con los trabajadores para ver lo de un posible paro de labores y advirtió que de pasar la reforma judicial en los términos que el presidente López Obrador “generaría serios problemas en el sistema de justicia y en la gente que permanece en prisión, esperando a que se resuelvan sus asuntos”. Te puede interesar > [La independencia judicial también es un derecho del pueblo: Norma Piña](https://aristeguinoticias.com/1208/mexico/la-independencia-judicial-tambien-es-un-derecho-del-pueblo-norma-pina/) “Esto va más allá de un paro de labores, si se aprueba la reforma justamente lo que AMLO dimensiona sobre la dilación de la justicia o la tardanza en resolver asuntos, es lo que va a pasar con el despido de los juzgadores”, sentenció.
